statement.tex: %text Sketch the graph of $y=\vert x + 3\vert$ and evaluate the area under the curve $y=\vert x+3\vert$ above x-axis and between $x=-6$ to $x=0$. %
\\ %text Which of the following curves is the plot for $y=\vert x+3\vert$ and correctly shows the required area? ($O$ is the origin) %
\\ %text \underline\text{Given the defintion of $\vert x+3\vert$} from the last step, what will the required area (A) be? %

reason.tex:
%text A very \underline\text{common mistake} is to say that \[ \qquad \vert x + 3\vert = \vert x\vert + 3\text{ (the wrong curve)} \]
This is simply not true.
To see why, \underline\text{let $ z = x + 3$}. Therefore % \vert x+3\vert = \vert z\vert = \begin{cases} -z\text{ if }z\lt 0 \implies x\lt -3, \\ z\text{ if }z\geq 0 \implies x\geq -3 \end{cases} \\ %text
\underline\text{In summary}, % \vert x + 3\vert = \begin{cases} -(x+3)\text{ if } x\lt -3 \\ (x+3)\text{ if } x\geq -3 \end{cases}

%text Recall that % \vert x + 3\vert = \begin{cases} -(x+3)\text{ if } x\lt -3 \\ (x+3)\text{ if } x\geq -3 \end{cases} \\ \begin{align} \therefore A &= \int_{-6}^{-3}-(x+3)\cdot dx + \int_{-3}^0 (x+3)\cdot dx\\ &= \underbrace{\int_{-3}^{-6}(x+3)\cdot dx}_{\text{Flipped the limits}} + \int_{-3}^0 (x+3)\cdot dx \\ &= \left[ \frac{x^2}{2} + 3x\right]_{-3}^{-6} + \left[ \frac{x^2}{2} + 3x\right]_{-3}^{0}\\ &= \left[ \left(18-18\right) - \left(\frac{9}{2}-9\right) \right] + \left[ 0 -\left(\frac{9}{2}-9\right)\right]\\ &= 9\text{ sq units} \end{align}
